_prev_prog_2.Description: Brenntag has taken all necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68.  The Executive Summary provides a description of each of the Accidental Release Prevention Program requirements including: Process Safety Information; Process Hazard Analysis; Operation Procedures; Training; Mechanical Integrity; Management of Change; Pre-startup Reviews; Compliance Audits; Incidental Investigation; Employee Participation and Contractor Requirements.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

The Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC facility is a chemical distribution facility located in Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin and headquartered in Wauwatosa, Wisconsin.  Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC is part of Brenntag North America Inc.  Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC is an advanced distribution company providing customers worldwide with products, chemicals and advanced materials.  Our major operations are located in the Midwest and employ approximately 240 people.

The Brenntag Great Lakes, LLC (Brenntag) facility, located in Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin, is a chemical distribution facility with an NAICS code of 42469.  Two of the chemicals handled at the facility trigger RMP threshold values.  These chemicals include Toluene Diisocyanate ? Mixed Isomers (TDI) and Cyclohexylamine.  The TDI storage process was previously reported to be a Program Level 1 process.  Cyclohexylamine is being reported in this Risk Management Plan submittal as a Program Level 2 process.  A release of Cyclohexylamine has been determined to be the worst-case release scenario.  An alternative release scenario is also included in this submittal for Cyclohexylamine.

It is the worldwide policy of Brenntag to design, blend and distribute its products, and to manage those products throughout their life cycle in a manner that protects the environment and safeguards employees, customers, and the public from unacceptable risk.  This facility participates in the Responsible Distribution Process program of the National Association of Chemical Distributors.  The Distribution Process program brings chemical distribution plants and local communities together through communication and cooperative emergency planning.  It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local regulations. 

Brenntag safety programs are designed to prevent fires, explosions, and accidental chemical releases.  The program requires safety audits, inspection, maintenance programs, and safety training for empl

oyees and contract workers.  Facility personnel are always encouraged to listen to the concerns of the community and to consider these concerns when designing and implementing process safety systems.

Brenntag maintains health, safety, and environmental manuals, which contain company policies for risk management, training, product stewardship, community outreach, and hazard communication among other topics.  The manuals also include emergency action plans, emergency response plans, and transportation emergency plans.  The facility is in compliance with OSHA regulations.

Brenntag has coordinated emergency response procedures with the Waukesha County - Division of Emergency Management.  These coordination efforts include both RMP chemicals; TDI and Cyclohexylamine.

In accordance with the RMP Submit Users Manual 2004, the following elements and their descriptions have been included in this Executive Summary:

1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Brenntag is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as; design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the various processes at the facility.  It is Brenntag's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur, Brenntag has thoroughly coordinated response efforts with the Menomonee Falls Fire Dept., which provides highly trained emergency response personnel to control and mitigate the effects of a release.

2.    The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
The Brenntag facility?s primary activities encompass distribution of chemical products.  There are currently two regulated substances present at the facility.  These substances include Toluene Diisocyanate ? Mixed Isomers (TDI), and Cyclohexylamine.  The TDI

and Cyclohexylamine are received in tankers and are drummed on site.  TDI is stored in larger storage tanks and is drummed into 250 gallon pressure-rated cylinders.  Cyclohexylamine is drummed into 55 gallon drums and stored on the floor or in racks until it can be transported to the Wauwatosa Warehouse facility.  TDI and Cyclohexylamine are materials only handled for repackaging and resale to customers and are not used in any processes on site. 

3.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The Brenntag facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the NFPA 30 Standard.

The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is currently in place at the stationary source.

Process Safety Information-Regional Manager of Health, Safety and Quality:
Brenntag maintains a detailed record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis- Regional Manager of Health, Safety and Quality (Chairman of the Hazard Process Review Team):
Brenntag conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the distribution processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is  ?WHAT IF?.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of three years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures-Warehouse Manager\Foreman:
Brenntag maintains written operating procedures for the purposes of safely conducting activities associated with the distribution processes.  These procedures address various mode

s of operation such as used in normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes.

Training-Manager of Health, Safety and Quality:
Brenntag has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees that are operating processes are completely competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  New employees receive basic training in process operations followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years, and more frequently, as needed.

Mechanical Integrity- Warehouse Manager\Foreman:
Brenntag carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper functions.  Maintenance checks are performed on process equipment also includes lift trucks and tractor/trailer trucks.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training, as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. Outside contractors also participate in the maintenance process.

Management of Change- Regional Manager of Health, Safety and Quality:
Written procedures are in place at Brenntag to manage changes in chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions, are promptly made aware of the modification and offered appropriate training.

Pre-startup Reviews- Regional Manager of Health, Safety and Quality:
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of established processes, are conducted as a regular practice at Brenntag

.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits- Regional Manager of Health, Safety and Quality:
Brenntag conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set forth under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions resulting from the audits are undertaken in a safe and timely manner.

Incident Investigation- Regional Manager of Health, Safety and Quality:                                                                         Brenntag promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are conducted to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as to determine corrective actions that will prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation-Operations Manager:
Brenntag truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, employees have access to all information developed for the RMP rule along with information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Contractors- Warehouse Manager\Foreman:
On occasion, Brenntag hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor?s safety performance is conducted.  Brenntag has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor?s work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event that a regulated substance is accidentally re

leased.

4.    Five-year Accident History
Brenntag has had zero accident releases in five years at this facility, with the exception of a TDI release/injury that occurred in April of 2007.  A Brenntag employee was completing maintenance on an empty TDI cylinder that still had remaining residue inside.  After forgetting to relieve any built up pressure from the cylinder, the employee opened the bottom plug and was sprayed in the face with TDI residue.  The employee had forgotten to wear his full face respirator that was supplied to him, which he had used on a regular basis during maintenance of these cylinders.  The injury that occurred included irritation to his eyes and respiratory system.  The employee immediately washed his eyes in the company eye wash station.  Eye washing continued in the ambulance and at the hospital.  Oxygen was also administered at the hospital where he was kept overnight for observation.   

5.    Emergency Response Plan
Brenntag has a written emergency response plan in place to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes that take place within the processes that would require a modified emergency response.

The Emergency Response Plan has been reviewed, coordinated and verified with Waukesha County - Division of Emergency Management, which is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Brenntag's safety program is designed to prevent fires, explosions, and accidental chemical releases.  The program requires safety audits, inspection, maintenance programs, and safety training for employe

es and contract workers.  Facility personnel are always encouraged to listen to the concerns of the community and to consider these concerns when designing and implementing process safety systems.

Brenntag continues to improve its safety record by conducting incident investigations and safety compliance audits.  Brenntag also utilizes continuous training on emergency procedures, and participating in outreach activities, which include: educating and training customers, fire departments, and emergency response teams.  Brenntag practices continuous training of emergency procedures through regular safety meetings, and all incidents and near misses are thoroughly investigated and reviewed by the Health and Safety personnel and the Safety Committee at each facility.

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the Brenntag accidental release prevention program.  Brenntag constantly strives to improve the safety of the processes at the facility through both the incident investigation program, and the safety committee.  Brenntag will continue to train employees in the operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be performed.

END
